questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath with exertion for the past year. She is unable to walk further than a few houses down the street or climb the stairs at her home. She has occasional palpitations and a dry cough. She lives independently with her husband and is capable of doing her household chores. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. Pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur and an early-diastolic heart sound are heard best at the cardiac apex. Bilateral crackles are heard on pulmonary examination. Further evaluation is most likely going to show which of the following findings?



Cardiac output
Pulmonary artery pressure
ST elevations on ECG
Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure



A
Decreased
increased
present
decreased


B
Increased
decreased
absent
decreased


C
Decreased
increased
absent
increased


D
Decreased
decreased
absent
decreased


E
Decreased
increased
present
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination would be consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE). PE can cause increased pulmonary artery pressure and decreased blood flow to the left ventricle, which leads to decreased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure and decreased cardiac output. ST elevations can occur in some cases of PE, although more commonly, ECG shows sinus tachycardia and signs of right ventricular pressure overload (e.g., S1Q3T3 pattern, new right bundle branch block). This patient lacks other typical features of PE, such as chest pain, decreased breath sounds, and an acute onset of symptoms. Also, PE would not explain findings on cardiac auscultation in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination would be consistent with some cases of distributive shock (e.g., early septic shock). Distributive shock is associated with inappropriate peripheral vasodilation and decreased venous return (causing↓ pulmonary artery pressure and↓ left ventricular end-diastolic pressure) and an increase in cardiac output (in early stages). This patient lacks other typical features of septic shock, including poor overall condition, fever, hypotension, and a history of infection. Also, septic shock would not explain auscultation findings on cardiac auscultation of the heart in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic MR leads to chronic volume overload of the left ventricle (LV) (normal stroke volume + regurgitated volume), which triggers eccentric hypertrophy of the left atrium and ventricle to compensate for the overload and maintain the cardiac output. Decompensation of chronic MR due to progressive LV dilation and myocardial dysfunction results in decreased stroke volume (↓ cardiac output), increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (due to↑ end-systolic and end-diastolic volume), and increased pulmonary artery pressure (blood backs up into pulmonary veins and ultimately pulmonary artery). Because chronic MR leads to LV hypertrophy, ECG changes can include deviation of the ST segment in the opposite direction of the QRS complex (discordance) and T-wave inversions.

Further features of chronic MR include palpitations (due to conduction abnormalities, e.g., atrial fibrillation) and an early-diastolic heart sound (S3 is a sign of diastolic ventricular volume overload).

D) INCORRECT:

This combination would be consistent with hypovolemia. Hypovolemia causes decreased blood return to the right atrium and lungs (indicated by↓ pulmonary artery pressure). Low right heart blood volume results in decreased blood delivery to the left ventricle (shown by↓ left ventricular end-diastolic pressure). Low left ventricular end-diastolic volume leads to decreased cardiac output. ST changes are not typically seen in patients with hypovolemia. While elderly people often have insufficient fluid intake, putting them at risk of hypovolemia, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of hypovolemia, such as dry skin, dizziness, and disorientation. Lastly, hypovolemia would not explain the findings on cardiac auscultation of the heart in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination would be consistent with acute left heart failure secondary to myocardial infarction (MI). MI can cause ventricular dysfunction (↓ cardiac output), which leads to increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (due to↑ end-systolic and end-diastolic volume) and increased pulmonary artery pressure (blood backs up into lungs and right heart). ST-segment elevation is a typical finding of MI (STEMI). This patient lacks other characteristic findings, such as retrosternal pain (although sometimes absent in older women and patients with diabetes), diaphoresis, nausea, and an acute onset of symptoms.
questions.hint: Features of left-sided heart failure (exertional dyspnea, exercise intolerance, dry cough, bilateral crackles on auscultation) in combination with a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex indicate chronic mitral valve regurgitation (MR).

questions.text: Three days after undergoing cardiac catheterization and coronary angioplasty for acute myocardial infarction, a 70-year-old man develops shortness of breath at rest. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, sublingual nitroglycerin, metoprolol, and insulin. He appears diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a new grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. An ECG shows sinus rhythm with T wave inversion in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular aneurysm can occur after myocardial infarction (MI) and it can manifest with symptoms of HF and even MR (as a result of tethering of the papillary muscles and/or annular dilation). However, ventricular aneurysm is a late complication of MI that appears weeks to months after infarction. In addition, other features are also expected, such as a double apical impulse, persistent ST elevation on ECG, and deep Q waves in the same leads.

B) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can result in tachycardia, tachypnea, and new-onset dyspnea within 1–3 days of myocardial infarction. However, other features such as chest pain and a pericardial friction rub would be expected. Moreover, the ECG in a patient with early infarct-associated pericarditis would typically show diffuse ST-segment elevations, which is not consistent with this patient's ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Heart rate approx. 70/min

- Regular sinus rhythm

- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in I and aVF)

- Normal narrow QRS complexes

- Concave ST elevation in multiple leads (I, II, V2–6; blue arrows), with reciprocal ST depression in aVR (red arrow).

- PR segment depression in multiple leads (II, V2, V4–V6; purple arrows)

Upward concave ST elevation and PR segment depression in multiple leads (with reciprocal ST depression usually confined to aVR/V1) are characteristic of acute pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal rupture usually occurs within 3–5 days after myocardial infarction and typically manifests with de novo HF and a new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, this condition does not cause MR, and the murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border rather than the apex. Moreover, patients typically present with features of predominant right-sided HF, such as increased jugular venous pressure and peripheral edema. In addition, an ECG would show new ST-segment changes, a heart block, decreased/absent Q waves, and/or large P waves (due to atrial overload).

D) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome can result in dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, postmyocardial infarction syndrome usually occurs 2–10 weeks after an MI, and other features such as chest pain and/or fever would be present. Moreover, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub instead of a new-onset holosystolic murmur, and the ECG would typically show ST-segment elevations in all leads.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery dissection is a complication of coronary angioplasty (PCI). Reinfarction due to coronary artery dissection can precipitate acute heart failure, which would result in new-onset dyspnea, and possibly a functional MR. However, coronary artery dissection due to PCI typically occurs during or immediately after the procedure, and other features such as new-onset chest pain as well as new ST-segment changes on ECG would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Ventricular free wall rupture, a complication that occurs within 3–14 days of myocardial infarction, would result in features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia) due to cardiac tamponade. However, a new-onset murmur is not a typical presentation of cardiac tamponade. Instead, muffled heart sounds on auscultation and other features such as new-onset chest pain, increased JVP, and pulsus paradoxus would be expected. The ECG would typically show low voltage ventricular complexes, electrical alternans, new ST-segment changes, and/or tall T waves in the precordial limbs, none of which are seen here.

G) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture, a life-threatening early complication of myocardial infarction (MI), typically develops within 2–7 days of MI and may cause acute MR. In addition to clinical features of acute left-sided HF and a systolic murmur, findings may also include a midsystolic click due to mitral valve prolapse. ECG findings are unspecific and may show T-wave inversion as a sign of previous and/or current cardiac ischemia. Papillary muscle rupture is more common in patients with involvement of the right coronary, which supplies the posteromedial papillary muscle through the posterior descending artery without any collateral blood supply. The diagnosis can be confirmed using echocardiography, which often shows flailing of a valve segment. The treatment of choice is surgical repair.

See “Overview of MI complications” table.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute pulmonary edema (dyspnea, tachypnea, bilateral crackles), hemodynamic compromise (decreased blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis), and a new systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex, all of which suggest de novo heart failure (HF) caused by acute mitral regurgitation (MR).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 months. The dyspnea occurs on moderate exertion and during the night; he sometimes wakes up coughing and “gasping for air.” He has also had several episodes of heart pounding. Two weeks ago, he had a runny nose and a productive cough. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. He has never smoked. He drinks one to two beers occasionally. He has a history of intravenous illicit drug use but has not used in over 25 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral basilar rales. Cardiac auscultation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) as the cause of his LHF. MR typically manifests with a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex. Mitral murmurs are heard best during expiration and while the patient lies on the left side. Causes of primary MR include degenerative mitral valve disease (mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae), infective endocarditis, and rheumatic fever.
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with some features of pericarditis including fatigue, palpitations, and exertional dyspnea, which are often preceded by flu-like symptoms. But he lacks other typical findings, such as fever, and sharp, pleuritic chest pain, and does not have a high-pitched scratching sound (pericardial friction rub) on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve regurgitation (TR) manifests with a holosystolic murmur and can occur as a result of infective endocarditis in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. However, the murmur of TR is heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of TR is intensified during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur is intensified on expiration. Moreover, TR is extremely rare and would typically manifest with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis (PS) primarily manifests during early childhood with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2nd left ICS. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of PS is intensified during deep inspiration rather than during expiration as in this patient. Moreover, PS is rare and would typically present with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

E) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic valve regurgitation, this condition would manifest with a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th ICSs and along the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by mitral valve stenosis (MS) and mitral murmurs are heard best at the apex, MS would manifest with a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble, and loud S1.
Image Description:

Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the mitral valve to completely open during diastole, impeding blood from flowing from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole. This generates a low-frequency mid-diastolic murmur that is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex and is often accompanied by a loud S1. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

G) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic stenosis, this condition would manifest with a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd ICS at the right upper sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.
questions.hint: This patient presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and features of pulmonary congestion (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar rales on auscultation). In combination with a heart murmur, these findings are highly suggestive of left-sided heart failure (LHF) caused by valvular heart disease. The auscultation findings reveal a systolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left intercostal space (ICS), the area of the cardiac apex.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath with exertion and intermittent palpitations over the last 2 months. She has had neither chest pain nor a cough. Her pulse is 124/min and irregular. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the apex and radiates to the back. The murmur increases in intensity when she clenches her hands into fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pulmonary artery thrombus on computed tomography scan
Obstruction of the right marginal artery on coronary angiogram
Reversible area of myocardial ischemia on nuclear stress test
Dilation of left atrium on echocardiogram

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary artery thrombus on CT is seen in pulmonary embolism (PE). While this condition can cause dyspnea, it typically manifests with an acute onset of cough, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distention. This patient's 2-month history of progressive shortness of breath and absence of chest pain and cough make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse ST elevations on ECG suggest acute pericarditis, which can cause dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests with an acute onset of severe chest pain that is relieved by sitting up and leaning forward, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation, neither of which are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the right marginal artery on a coronary angiogram is consistent with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which typically presents with acute retrosternal chest pain/pressure, radiation to the jaw and/or left arm, shortness of breath, and nausea/vomiting. It also produces symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to reduced blood supply of the right ventricle, such as jugular venous distention. However, these symptoms are not present here, and this patient's progressive 2-month history of increasing dyspnea makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, a significant systolic murmur characteristic of mitral regurgitation requires a different diagnostic method than an angiogram.

D) INCORRECT:

Reversible myocardial ischemia due to CAD can be diagnosed by a nuclear stress test that includes myocardial perfusion imaging (MIBI). While this condition also causes shortness of breath, it typically presents with an acute onset of retrosternal pain/pressure that may radiate to the jaw and/or left arm, and autonomic symptoms such as sweating, pallor, and nausea/vomiting, which are not present here.

E) CORRECT:

Dilatation of the left atrium (LA) results from volume and pressure overload due to chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) in this patient. LA enlargement can cause atrial fibrillation, which explains the tachycardia and irregular heartbeat seen here. Echocardiography would be the best diagnostic method for visualizing the suspected structural and flow abnormalities of MR.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)
questions.hint: A high-pitched, holosystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the back and higher intensity with increased systemic vascular resistance (hand grip, squatting) in a patient with exertional dyspnea is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that radiates to the axilla and an extra heart sound during early diastole. Assuming all other parameters remain constant, which of the following is most likely to decrease the volume of retrograde blood flow in this patient?

choices.text: Decrease in left atrial systolic pressure
Increase in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The left atrioventricular orifice is formed by the mitral valve annulus. In the case of mitral regurgitation, an increase in the size of this annulus would increase rather than decrease retrograde blood flow (regurgitation).

B) INCORRECT:

The left atrial systolic pressure acts as a resistance to retrograde blood flow across the mitral valve. Therefore, a decrease in left atrial systolic pressure would increase rather than decrease the volume of regurgitated blood.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased left ventricular inotropy would increase the ejection fraction and thereby decrease the left ventricular end diastolic volume. In a patient with mitral valve incompetence, as seen here, this phenomenon would be expected to decrease the regurgitant fraction (retrograde blood flow) across the mitral valve in the next cardiac cycle. However, this effect of increased LV inotropy is counteracted by the increase in left ventricular systolic pressure, which tends to increase regurgitant blood flow. Overall, increased LV inotropy does not result in a specific or predictable change in the regurgitant volume, as has been shown empirically in studies with dobutamine (an inotropic drug).

Inotropic drugs are used in patients with cardiogenic shock due to acute mitral regurgitation but this is done in order to improve the cardiac output, not to decrease retrograde blood flow.

D) CORRECT:

A decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) would reduce the volume of retrograde blood flow through the mitral valve. In mitral regurgitation (MR), the left ventricular ejection fraction is divided between the output through the aortic valve and through the abnormal regurgitant mitral valve. When SVR (left ventricular afterload) is decreased, a greater volume of blood is ejected through the aortic valve and less blood flows in a retrograde direction across the mitral valve (lower regurgitant fraction). This is the rationale for using systemic vasodilators (e.g., sodium nitroprusside) to treat dyspnea in patients with severe acute MR. Conversely, maneuvers such as isometric contraction and a hand grip, which increase SVR, reduce ejection fraction through the aortic valve and increase the retrograde flow.

E) INCORRECT:

As retrograde flow is dependent on the pressure gradient between the LV and left atrium, an increase in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) would increase the driving pressure and increase retrograde blood flow.
questions.hint: A holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the cardiac apex and radiates to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation (MR). The extra heart sound during diastole is most likely an S3 gallop, which is often heard in patients with moderate to severe MR.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is admitted to the hospital because of shortness of breath and fatigue 2 weeks after delivery of a full-term female newborn. She has no history of major medical illness. Cardiac examination on admission shows an S3 gallop and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. Treatment is initiated with intravenous furosemide and captopril. Her symptoms resolve, and 3 weeks later, cardiac examination shows no murmur. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the initial auscultation findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. Patients with dilated cardiomyopathy can develop mitral regurgitation caused by left ventricular failure and/or dilation of the mitral valve annulus. Dilated cardiomyopathy caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy is typically reversible. Heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, S3 gallop) and mitral regurgitation can be treated with diuretics.
Image Description:

Systolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:
(A) Mitral/tricuspid regurgitation and/or ventricular septal defect (holosystolic murmur)
(B) Aortic/pulmonary stenosis (crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(C) Aortic/pulmonary stenosis with an ejection click
(D) Mitral valve prolapse (midsystolic click followed by crescendo murmur)
(E) Pulmonary stenosis with a split second heart sound

B) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve, which occurs in connective tissue diseases (e.g., Marfan syndrome), can lead to mitral regurgitation; but such a valvular defect is irreversible without surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Perivalvular abscesses occur in individuals with infective endocarditis and can cause severe mitral regurgitation, which is seen here. However, valvular defects due to infective endocarditis are usually irreversible and require treatment with high-dose antibiotic therapy as well as surgical repair.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the mitral valve leaflets, which is seen in rheumatic heart disease (RHD), can cause mitral regurgitation or mitral stenosis; but valvular defects due to RHD are irreversible and require surgical repair.

E) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture, which typically occurs following myocardial infarction, can lead to mitral regurgitation but is irreversible without surgery.

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral annular calcification can lead to mitral regurgitation, but this condition typically occurs in the older population. Furthermore, mitral annular calcification is irreversible without surgery.
questions.hint: The presentation of shortness of breath, fatigue, and a murmur of mitral regurgitation in the early peripartum period suggests peripartum cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of exertional shortness of breath and fatigue. She sometimes wakes up at night coughing and gasping for air. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Which of the following physical exam findings would be consistent with an exacerbation of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Paradoxical splitting of A2 and P2
Radiation of the murmur to the axilla

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (A2 and P2) is seen in conditions that delay aortic valve closure such as aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS). Both these conditions can present with exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, fatigue, and a cardiac murmur, as seen here. However, the murmur of AR is a decrescendo, early diastolic murmur, and the murmur of AS is a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection. Also, both these murmurs would be best heard at the right upper sternal border (aortic area) rather than the cardiac apex. This patient's auscultatory finding is suggestive of mitral regurgitation, which is not associated with a paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of a diastolic extra heart sound (S3) is associated with an exacerbation of a pre-existing MR. Patients with chronic mitral valve insufficiency have an elevated ventricular volume and pressure during diastole as a result of insufficient valve closure, which leads to backflow of blood through the mitral valves. This higher blood volume entering the left ventricle during diastole results in an S3 heart sound on auscultation (ventricular filling sound). The presence of an S3 heart sound is associated with advanced-stage or a severe MR.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

C) INCORRECT:

A prominent V wave on jugular venous examination (Lancisi sign) due to the merging of the V wave with the C wave is a sign of exacerbation in tricuspid regurgitation (TR). Severe TR can manifest with exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, fatigue, and a holosystolic murmur but the murmur would be best heard at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area), not at the cardiac apex.

D) INCORRECT:

Head bobbing is a characteristic physical exam finding in patients with aortic regurgitation (AR). Although AR may present with exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and fatigue, the murmur is classically early diastolic, decrescendo, and best heard at the right upper sternal border, unlike the holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex here.

E) INCORRECT:

The absence of an A2 heart sound can be seen in severe aortic stenosis (AS). The second heart sound (S2) is composed of two parts, the A2 (closure of aortic valves) and the P2 (closure of pulmonic valves) sound. The A2 heart sound typically occurs prior to the P2 and is a very soft heart sound. In severe AS, the aortic valve may remain open until later in diastole, causing the P2 heart sound to drown out the A2. Patients with AS often have exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and fatigue. However, AS presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border, not a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex.

F) INCORRECT:

Radiation of the murmur to the axilla is commonly seen in patients with MR. However, radiation of the murmur to the axilla is not suggestive of MR exacerbation.
questions.hint: A holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex suggests mitral regurgitation (MR).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and progressively worsening shortness of breath that is worse when lying down. Recently, he started using two pillows to avoid waking up short of breath at night. Examination shows a heart murmur. A graph with the results of cardiac catheterization is shown. Given this patient's valvular condition, which of the following murmurs is most likely to be heard on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: High-pitched, holosystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla
Rumbling, delayed diastolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex
Blowing, early diastolic murmur heard best at the Erb point
High-frequency, diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd left intercostal space
Harsh, late systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A high-pitched, holosystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla is typically heard in severe cases of mitral regurgitation (MR). MR can manifest with dyspnea, cough, and other symptoms of left heart failure (e.g., fatigue, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). This patient's cardiac catheterization shows a rapid increase in left atrial (LA) pressure during ventricular systole, a finding that is characteristic of MR. The LA pressure increases as blood enters the atrium both antegrade through the pulmonary veins and retrograde from the left ventricle (LV) through the regurgitant mitral valve.

B) INCORRECT:

A rumbling, delayed diastolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis (MS). In contrast to the findings in this patient, cardiac catheterization would reveal a left atrial pressure that is significantly higher than the left ventricular pressure during the ventricular filling phase (i.e., diastole). This increase in pressure occurs as the left atrium contracts to fill the left ventricle across the stenotic mitral valve.

C) INCORRECT:

A blowing, early diastolic murmur heard best at the Erb point is a characteristic of aortic regurgitation (AR). Unlike the pressure changes seen here, cardiac catheterization in a patient with AR would typically show increased aortic systolic pressure (regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the LV leads to higher preload and stroke volume) and decreased diastolic aortic pressure (due to rapid return of blood to the LV through the insufficient aortic valve). Consequently, there would be an increase in pulse pressure, which can manifest with water hammer pulse and the de Musset sign.

D) INCORRECT:

A high-frequency, diastolic murmur heard best at the second left intercostal space indicates pulmonary regurgitation. On cardiac catheterization, pulmonary regurgitation is associated with increased end-diastolic right ventricular pressure due to the increased backflow of blood across the regurgitant pulmonary valve during diastole. However, this graph shows the pressure changes in the left rather than the right heart.

E) INCORRECT:

A harsh, late systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids is characteristic of aortic stenosis. Unlike the pressure changes seen here, cardiac catheterization in AS typically shows a peak ventricular pressure that is significantly higher than the peak aortic pressure. This finding is a result of the elevated ventricular pressure required to pump blood through the stenotic aortic valve before the return to normal systolic pressure in the aorta. However, cardiac catheterization in this patient shows a peak ventricular pressure that is identical to the peak aortic pressure.
questions.hint: The murmur can be intensified by a handgrip maneuver.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes reports new-onset mild dyspnea on exertion during the past several months. He has rheumatoid arthritis and moderate mitral regurgitation, for which he has been followed with a yearly echocardiogram. His only medications are aspirin, simvastatin, and hydroxychloroquine.
On examination, the patient has normal vital signs, normal jugular venous pressure, clear lungs, a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that radiates to the axilla, and trace lower-extremity edema. His electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm at 70 beats per minute, with nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave abnormalities.
A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals severe mitral regurgitation, which has worsened since the previous study. There is bileaflet mitral valve prolapse and a new flail posterior leaflet segment. The left ventricular ejection fraction is 60%. Given the patient’s symptoms and echocardiographic findings, he is referred for mitral valve repair.
Which one of the following preoperative tests is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Pharmacologic stress testing with myocardial perfusion imaging

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is often performed before valve surgery if the severity or mechanism of the valvular abnormality is unclear, and most centers routinely use TEE during surgery. However, if a transthoracic echocardiogram has previously identified the severity and mechanism of mitral regurgitation, preoperative TEE is unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is unlikely to provide relevant additional information in this clinical setting.

C) CORRECT:

A patient with severe, symptomatic mitral regurgitation referred for elective valve surgery should undergo preoperative cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography to assess for the presence and severity of obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD). If CAD is present, concomitant coronary artery bypass grafting at the time of valve surgery is recommended. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography should be performed before elective valve surgery in patients with known or suspected CAD (those with anginal chest pain, decreased left ventricular systolic function, or objective evidence of myocardial ischemia, or CAD risk factors) and in patients “at risk” for CAD (men ≥35 years of age, premenopausal women ≥35 years of age who have CAD risk factors, and postmenopausal women).

Key learning point: In a patient referred for elective valve surgery who is at risk for coronary artery disease, the most appropriate preoperative test is cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography.

D) INCORRECT:

A stress test cannot satisfactorily identify (or exclude) CAD.

E) INCORRECT:

A stress test cannot satisfactorily identify (or exclude) CAD.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic fever was diagnosed with moderate mitral regurgitation 3 years ago, after a holosystolic murmur was found during a routine physical examination. She has been followed every 6 months since then with serial physical examinations and echocardiograms and presents now for routine follow-up. She has no symptoms and is able to perform all of her activities of daily living without any problems.
On examination, she has a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 122/68 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. Her lungs are clear, and she has a loud holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex with no jugular venous distention or edema.
Her electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm and is otherwise normal. Her echocardiogram shows moderate mitral regurgitation, a left ventricular end-systolic dimension of 42 mm, a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 55 mm Hg, and an ejection fraction of 55% (down from 65% on prior study) with good wall motion and no enlargement of the ventricle.
What is the most important next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend amoxicillin before major dental procedures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy has a limited role in the management of asymptomatic patients with mitral regurgitation. Beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors along with other standard medical therapy for heart failure would be appropriate in a patient with symptomatic mitral regurgitation. However, in this asymptomatic patient, there is no convincing evidence that medical management would alter the course of the mitral valve disease, which clearly requires surgical intervention at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has echocardiographic evidence of pulmonary hypertension. As mitral valve regurgitation progresses, pulmonary hypertension, left atrial enlargement, and atrial fibrillation are all common sequelae. All can contribute to the decision for mitral valve repair, but none are as strong an indication for repair as symptoms or loss of left ventricular function. Sildenafil is indicated for primary pulmonary hypertension, but in this patient, mitral valve repair is the appropriate management option, not medical therapy for pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is given before dental procedures for prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis. However, this patient does not have an indication for such prophylaxis. In her case, monthly penicillin G therapy is indicated for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever.

D) CORRECT:

The natural history of mitral regurgitation is one of progression, but the timing of surgical intervention depends on the risks and benefits of repair. There are two clear indications for valve repair in chronic mitral regurgitation: (1) symptoms, and (2) a reduction in left ventricular systolic function to less than 60% and/or a left ventricular end-systolic dimension ≥40 mm. Although an ejection fraction of 55% in patients without mitral regurgitation may be considered normal, in patients with mitral regurgitation, an ejection fraction below 60% is associated with rapidly declining 10-year survival. This patient is asymptomatic but has an ejection fraction of 55%; thus, prompt mitral valve repair is indicated. This is true even though her mitral regurgitation is only moderate and she does not have another strong indication for repair.

Key learning point: In an asymptomatic patient with mitral valve regurgitation, one indication for valve repair is a left ventricular systolic ejection fraction below 60%.

E) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy has a limited role in the management of asymptomatic patients with mitral regurgitation. Beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors along with other standard medical therapy for heart failure would be appropriate in a patient with symptomatic mitral regurgitation. However, in this asymptomatic patient, there is no convincing evidence that medical management would alter the course of the mitral valve disease, which clearly requires surgical intervention at this point.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressively worsening shortness of breath with exertion and intermittent palpitations over the last 2 months. She has had neither chest pain nor a cough. Her pulse is 124/min and irregular. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the apex and radiates to the back. The murmur increases in intensity when she clenches her hands into fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pulmonary artery thrombus on computed tomography scan
Obstruction of the right marginal artery on coronary angiogram
Reversible area of myocardial ischemia on nuclear stress test
Dilation of left atrium on echocardiogram

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary artery thrombus on CT is seen in pulmonary embolism (PE). While this condition can cause dyspnea, it typically manifests with an acute onset of cough, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distention. This patient's 2-month history of progressive shortness of breath and absence of chest pain and cough make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse ST elevations on ECG suggest acute pericarditis, which can cause dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests with an acute onset of severe chest pain that is relieved by sitting up and leaning forward, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation, neither of which are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the right marginal artery on a coronary angiogram is consistent with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which typically presents with acute retrosternal chest pain/pressure, radiation to the jaw and/or left arm, shortness of breath, and nausea/vomiting. It also produces symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to reduced blood supply of the right ventricle, such as jugular venous distention. However, these symptoms are not present here, and this patient's progressive 2-month history of increasing dyspnea makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, a significant systolic murmur characteristic of mitral regurgitation requires a different diagnostic method than an angiogram.

D) INCORRECT:

Reversible myocardial ischemia due to CAD can be diagnosed by a nuclear stress test that includes myocardial perfusion imaging (MIBI). While this condition also causes shortness of breath, it typically presents with an acute onset of retrosternal pain/pressure that may radiate to the jaw and/or left arm, and autonomic symptoms such as sweating, pallor, and nausea/vomiting, which are not present here.

E) CORRECT:

Dilatation of the left atrium (LA) results from volume and pressure overload due to chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) in this patient. LA enlargement can cause atrial fibrillation, which explains the tachycardia and irregular heartbeat seen here. Echocardiography would be the best diagnostic method for visualizing the suspected structural and flow abnormalities of MR.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)
questions.hint: A high-pitched, holosystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the back and higher intensity with increased systemic vascular resistance (hand grip, squatting) in a patient with exertional dyspnea is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and exertional shortness of breath. He sometimes wakes up coughing and gasping for air. Two months ago, he emigrated from Bangladesh. He does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Auscultation of the lungs shows crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology. RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with progressive exertional shortness of breath over 3 months. On auscultation, there is a high-pitched blowing murmur spanning from the first to second heart sound, best heard at the cardiac apex. The murmur becomes louder with handgrip exercise and softer with Valsalva. Jugular venous pressure is normal, and there is no lower extremity edema.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains his murmur?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation manifests with a holosystolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. This murmur results from regurgitant flow from the left ventricle into the left atrium during systole. The murmur intensifies with handgrip exercise, which increases afterload, and diminishes with the Valsalva maneuver, which reduces preload. These auscultatory findings, along with progressive exertional shortness of breath, indicate chronic volume overload of the left atrium and ventricle, characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

Key learning point: A systolic murmur at the apex that increases with handgrip and decreases with Valsalva is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. The murmur decreases with handgrip exercise due to increased afterload reducing the outflow tract gradient. Valsalva typically accentuates the murmur, but the patient's murmur softens with Valsalva, indicating a regurgitant lesion rather than dynamic obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids. The murmur is not high-pitched or blowing and does not increase with handgrip exercise. The murmur's location at the apex and its response to maneuvers suggest a regurgitant process, not the fixed outflow obstruction of aortic stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is associated with a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur, not a blowing murmur spanning S1 to S2. Handgrip exercise usually reduces prolapse, diminishing the murmur, while Valsalva accentuates the click and murmur. The patient's murmur characteristics and response to maneuvers do not align with mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion for the past three months. He reports orthopnea and occasional palpitations. He has a long-standing history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Examination reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, radiating to the axilla, an S3 gallop, and bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Despite optimized guideline-directed medical therapy for systolic heart failure, his symptoms remain unchanged (see report).


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg


Echocardiogram: Severely dilated left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 30%; severe mitral regurgitation with a regurgitant fraction of 60%
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with severe mitral regurgitation, especially with left ventricular dilation and reduced ejection fraction (30%), surgical intervention is crucial. Persistent symptoms despite optimized heart failure therapy indicate that the regurgitation is causing adverse remodeling and symptomatic deterioration. Echocardiographic findings show significant hemodynamic burden, justifying surgical valve replacement. In cases of rheumatic pathology, structural changes often preclude successful repair, making replacement the preferred option. This intervention reduces volume load, diminishes left ventricular remodeling, and aligns with current evidence-based practices for managing severe, symptomatic mitral regurgitation.

Key learning point: In patients with severe symptomatic mitral regurgitation and reduced ejection fraction, surgical intervention such as mitral valve replacement is often necessary to improve symptoms and prevent further cardiac deterioration.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is used in heart failure patients with electrical dyssynchrony, indicated by reduced ejection fraction and prolonged QRS duration. This patient lacks evidence of conduction delays. CRT does not address the hemodynamic burden of severe mitral regurgitation, which is the primary issue here.

C) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics relieve symptoms of volume overload by decreasing preload and pulmonary congestion. However, they do not address the underlying mitral regurgitation or its impact on cardiac remodeling. Increasing diuretics may offer transient relief but risks electrolyte disturbances and renal dysfunction without modifying the regurgitant lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous mitral balloon valvuloplasty is for symptomatic mitral stenosis with favorable valve morphology. This patient has severe mitral regurgitation, not stenosis. The procedure does not address the backward flow of blood in regurgitant lesions, making it inappropriate for this scenario.

questions.text: A 12-year-old with recent streptococcal pharyngitis presents with migratory polyarthritis, chest pain, and a new holosystolic murmur. Which valvular abnormality is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation is characterized by a diastolic decrescendo murmur, not a holosystolic murmur. In rheumatic heart disease, aortic regurgitation would present with signs like widened pulse pressure and bounding pulses, which are absent here. The holosystolic murmur and acute symptoms align more with mitral valve involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis is a chronic complication of rheumatic heart disease, resulting from long-term inflammatory damage leading to fibrosis and commissural fusion. It typically presents years after the initial rheumatic fever episode. The holosystolic murmur in this patient indicates regurgitation, not the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis. The acute presentation with migratory polyarthritis and chest pain suggests an inflammatory process causing regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis presents with an ejection systolic murmur, not a holosystolic murmur. It is typically associated with congenital anomalies in children, not acute rheumatic fever. The patient's symptoms and murmur suggest acute rheumatic carditis with mitral regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

D) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever, following streptococcal infection, can lead to an autoimmune response targeting cardiac tissues, particularly affecting the mitral valve. This results in inflammation and edema, impairing valve closure during systole and causing mitral regurgitation. The holosystolic murmur arises from blood regurgitating from the left ventricle to the left atrium. In the acute phase, regurgitation is more common than stenosis, as fibrosis and scarring develop over years. Migratory polyarthritis and chest pain further support the diagnosis of acute rheumatic carditis with mitral regurgitation.

Key learning point: Mitral valve regurgitation is the most common echocardiographic finding in acute rheumatic fever due to inflammation and damage to the valve leaflets.

questions.text: You are caring for a 70-year-old man who, three days after cardiac catheterization and coronary angioplasty for acute myocardial infarction, develops shortness of breath at rest. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, sublingual nitroglycerin, metoprolol, and insulin. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. On examination, crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a new grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. ECG shows sinus rhythm with T wave inversion in leads II, III, and aVF. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture, a life-threatening early complication of myocardial infarction (MI), typically develops within 2–7 days of MI and may cause acute MR. In addition to clinical features of acute left-sided HF and a systolic murmur, findings may also include a midsystolic click due to mitral valve prolapse. ECG findings are unspecific and may show T-wave inversion as a sign of previous and/or current cardiac ischemia. Papillary muscle rupture is more common in patients with involvement of the right coronary, which supplies the posteromedial papillary muscle through the posterior descending artery without any collateral blood supply. The diagnosis can be confirmed using echocardiography, which often shows flailing of a valve segment. The treatment of choice is surgical repair.

See “Overview of MI complications” table.

Key learning point: Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication occurring 2–7 days after myocardial infarction, leading to acute mitral regurgitation, new holosystolic murmur at the apex, and acute left-sided heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal rupture usually occurs within 3–5 days after myocardial infarction and typically manifests with de novo HF and a new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, this condition does not cause MR, and the murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border rather than the apex. Moreover, patients typically present with features of predominant right-sided HF, such as increased jugular venous pressure and peripheral edema. In addition, an ECG would show new ST-segment changes, a heart block, decreased/absent Q waves, and/or large P waves (due to atrial overload).

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular aneurysm can occur after myocardial infarction (MI) and it can manifest with symptoms of HF and even MR (as a result of tethering of the papillary muscles and/or annular dilation). However, ventricular aneurysm is a late complication of MI that appears weeks to months after infarction. In addition, other features are also expected, such as a double apical impulse, persistent ST elevation on ECG, and deep Q waves in the same leads.

D) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome can result in dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, postmyocardial infarction syndrome usually occurs 2–10 weeks after an MI, and other features such as chest pain and/or fever would be present. Moreover, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub instead of a new-onset holosystolic murmur, and the ECG would typically show ST-segment elevations in all leads.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular free wall rupture, a complication that occurs within 3–14 days of myocardial infarction, would result in features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia) due to cardiac tamponade. However, a new-onset murmur is not a typical presentation of cardiac tamponade. Instead, muffled heart sounds on auscultation and other features such as new-onset chest pain, increased JVP, and pulsus paradoxus would be expected. The ECG would typically show low voltage ventricular complexes, electrical alternans, new ST-segment changes, and/or tall T waves in the precordial limbs, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute pulmonary edema (dyspnea, tachypnea, bilateral crackles), hemodynamic compromise (decreased blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis), and a new systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex, all of which suggest de novo heart failure (HF) caused by acute mitral regurgitation (MR).

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He reports occasionally waking up at night coughing and gasping for air. He emigrated from Bangladesh 2 months ago. He does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. On auscultation, there are crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination reveals a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology. RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

Key learning point: A high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, often due to rheumatic heart disease in individuals from developing countries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and intermittent palpitations. She denies chest pain or cough. Her pulse is 124/min and irregular. On examination, there is a grade 4/6 high-pitched holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex and radiating to the back, which increases in intensity with handgrip. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Reversible area of myocardial ischemia on nuclear stress test.
Dilation of left atrium on echocardiogram.
Pulmonary artery thrombus on computed tomography scan.
Obstruction of the right marginal artery on coronary angiogram.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reversible myocardial ischemia due to stable coronary artery disease (CAD) can be diagnosed by a nuclear stress test that includes myocardial perfusion imaging (MIBI). While this condition also causes exertional shortness of breath, papillary muscle rupture and mitral regurgitation are not expected with stable CAD. A different finding is more likely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Dilatation of the left atrium (LA) results from volume and pressure overload due to chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) in this patient. LA enlargement can cause atrial fibrillation, which explains the tachycardia and irregular heartbeat seen here. Echocardiography would be the best diagnostic method for visualizing the suspected structural and flow abnormalities of MR.

Key learning point: Chronic mitral regurgitation leads to left atrial dilation and atrial fibrillation.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, but the onset of symptoms is typically acute as opposed to the chronic, progressive nature of this patient's symptoms. Other symptoms of pulmonary embolism include pleuritic chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient's findings are consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF) due to valvular heart disease. In a patient with AF, a thrombus most commonly develops in the left atrial appendage.

D) INCORRECT:

Diffuse ST elevations on ECG suggest acute pericarditis, which can cause dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests with an acute onset of severe chest pain that is relieved by sitting up and leaning forward, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation, neither of which are present.

E) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the right marginal artery causes acute coronary syndrome if nearly complete; partial and stable obstruction results in chronic exertional chest pain or angina equivalents. This branch mainly supplies the right ventricle, so significant disease causes right-sided heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention). Acute occlusion could theoretically involve the anterior papillary muscles of the tricuspid valve, but its dual arterial supply makes rupture rare. Moreover, tricuspid regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that typically decreases with handgrip and is best heard at the tricuspid area.
questions.hint: A high-pitched, holosystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the back and higher intensity with increased systemic vascular resistance (hand grip, squatting) in a patient with exertional dyspnea is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over the past few weeks. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 108; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, lateral displacement of the apical impulse, and a holosystolic murmur at the apex. Chest x-ray is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of severe heart failure symptoms, holosystolic murmur at the apex, lateral displacement of the apical impulse, and cardiomegaly indicates severe chronic mitral regurgitation. Severity is determined by the presence of symptomatic heart failure, left ventricular dilatation (evidenced by displaced apical impulse), and cardiac remodeling (cardiomegaly), which occur in chronic volume overload from severe regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mild mitral regurgitation does not cause severe heart failure symptoms or cardiac remodeling. The displaced apical impulse and cardiomegaly indicate chronic left ventricular dilatation from severe, not mild, regurgitation. Additionally, patients with acute disease would not have time to develop these structural changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic stenosis produces a harsh systolic murmur at the right sternal border radiating to the carotids, not a holosystolic murmur at the apex. The murmur location and character are inconsistent with aortic stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Mild aortic stenosis would not cause severe heart failure symptoms or cardiac remodeling. Additionally, aortic stenosis produces a murmur at the right sternal border, not the apex.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe tricuspid regurgitation causes a systolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that increases with inspiration. The apical location and left ventricular dilatation point to mitral, not tricuspid, pathology.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease presents with acute onset of severe dyspnea and orthopnea that began 3 hours ago while sleeping. He appears distressed and is unable to speak in full sentences. Vital signs are BP, 90/60 mm Hg; P, 110; R, 28; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); oxygen saturation, 88% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, bibasilar crackles, and a soft decrescendo murmur best heard at the apex. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Chest x-ray shows pulmonary edema with a normal cardiac silhouette. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

BNP levels are useful for diagnostic confirmation in acute heart failure, but the clinical presentation and chest x-ray findings already strongly suggest acute heart failure. An alternate diagnostic test is more valuable to evaluate the suspected underlying valvular abnormality and determine the need for urgent intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has acute mitral regurgitation based on their clinical presentation. Blood cultures are indicated when infective endocarditis is suspected as a cause of a new valvulopathy. However, the absence of fever and lack of other clinical features suggesting endocarditis make this less likely. The priority in this patient is to confirm the valvulopathy and assess its severity.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has acute mitral regurgitation based on their clinical presentation. Cardiac MRI is reserved for cases in which echocardiographic findings are inconclusive or for detailed tissue characterization. The study is not appropriate for the initial evaluation of hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected acute valvular disease.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the modality of choice for initial assessment of suspected acute mitral regurgitation, which this patient most likely has based on their clinical presentation. TTE allows rapid bedside evaluation of valve function, left ventricular size and function, and severity of regurgitation. This information is critical for determining immediate management and the need for urgent surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has acute mitral regurgitation based on their clinical presentation. Coronary angiography is not the first-line diagnostic modality to confirm the diagnosis and assess severity. However, it may be considered after initial stabilization and evaluation, particularly if ischemic mitral regurgitation is suspected.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents with acute-onset dyspnea and orthopnea that began 3 hours ago. Vital signs are BP, 90/55; P, 120; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles, cool extremities, and a soft systolic murmur at the apex. Lung point-of-care ultrasound and ECG are shown. Troponin is mildly elevated. Supplemental oxygen is started. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has acute mitral regurgitation with cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema based on the acute onset, apical murmur, hypotension, ECG showing sinus tachycardia without ischemia, and lung ultrasound with B-lines confirming pulmonary edema. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement is indicated as a bridging device in patients whose symptoms continue to deteriorate despite medical therapy or as preparation for surgery, but would typically be considered after initial medical stabilization attempts have been made.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient likely has acute mitral regurgitation (MR) with cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema based on the acute presentation, apical systolic murmur, hypotension, ECG showing sinus tachycardia without ischemia, and lung ultrasound with B-lines confirming pulmonary edema. Dobutamine provides inotropic support to improve cardiac output and forward flow, which is the most appropriate initial management of cardiogenic shock associated with acute MR.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has acute mitral regurgitation with cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema based on the clinical presentation and lung ultrasound showing B-lines. While nitroprusside reduces afterload and can improve forward flow in acute MR, it may worsen hypotension in patients with cardiogenic shock. Afterload reduction with vasodilators is generally reserved for patients with preserved blood pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has acute mitral regurgitation with cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema, confirmed by lung ultrasound showing B-lines. Aggressive diuresis may worsen hypotension in cardiogenic shock, and while furosemide can treat pulmonary edema, it reduces preload and may further compromise cardiac output in hemodynamically unstable patients.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has acute mitral regurgitation (MR) with cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema based on the clinical presentation, ECG, and lung ultrasound findings. Management of cardiogenic shock of the "wet and cold" type is best achieved by first administering inotropes to increase cardiac output and peripheral perfusion, then adding pure vasopressors like norepinephrine if shock persists despite inotropic support. Norepinephrine also increases afterload in this patient, potentially worsening the degree of mitral regurgitation and pulmonary edema, thereby precipitating respiratory failure that would require mechanical ventilation. Therefore, norepinephrine is not the ideal first intervention to stabilize this patient's hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who immigrated from Southeast Asia 15 years ago presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. She recalls a childhood illness with fever and migratory joint pains. Her pulse is 98/min, and her blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a displaced, hyperdynamic apical impulse. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla. An S3 gallop is present. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a thickened mitral valve with restricted leaflet motion, severe mitral regurgitation, a dilated left atrium, and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 55%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiation of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and a diuretic
Initiation of a calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These medications are used to manage symptoms of heart failure. Although this patient is symptomatic, medical therapy does not address the underlying mechanical problem of the severely regurgitant valve. In a patient who is a surgical candidate with clear indications for intervention, medical therapy may be used as a bridge to surgery but is not the definitive next step.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers do not have a primary role in the management of chronic MR. Dihydropyridine agents can decrease afterload and potentially worsen the regurgitant volume. Non-dihydropyridine agents have negative inotropic effects that could be detrimental in a patient with borderline left ventricular function.

C) INCORRECT:

A strategy of watchful waiting with serial echocardiography is appropriate for asymptomatic patients with severe MR and preserved left ventricular function (LVEF > 60%). This patient is symptomatic and has evidence of left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 55%), which makes observation inappropriate.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has symptomatic (dyspnea, orthopnea) severe chronic MR, likely from rheumatic heart disease, as suggested by her history and echocardiogram findings. The presence of symptoms is an indication for intervention. Furthermore, her echocardiogram shows evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction. An LVEF of 55% is considered impaired in patients with severe MR because the ventricle unloads into the low-pressure left atrium, artificially inflating the true ejection fraction. The threshold for intervention is an LVEF ≤ 60%. Therefore, mitral valve surgery (repair or replacement) is indicated to correct the valvular lesion, prevent irreversible left ventricular damage, and improve symptoms and long-term survival.
questions.hint: This patient has symptomatic, severe mitral regurgitation (MR) with echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular dysfunction. The goal of management is to intervene before irreversible damage occurs.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and fatigue two weeks after being discharged for a myocardial infarction (MI). His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg and pulse is 95/min. Physical examination shows a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse. Auscultation reveals a new murmur and bibasilar crackles. Which of the following is the most likely auscultatory finding?

choices.text: A mid-diastolic rumbling murmur at the cardiac apex
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border
A soft, decrescendo murmur at the cardiac apex
A harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
A decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes the murmur of mitral stenosis. Mitral stenosis is a chronic condition, almost always resulting from rheumatic heart disease, and would not present as a new murmur two weeks after an MI. Although the location is the cardiac apex, the timing of the murmur (diastolic) and the cause are inconsistent with the clinical scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

This describes the murmur of aortic stenosis. While common in this age group, aortic stenosis is a chronic condition that would not develop acutely after an MI. The murmur is also located at the right upper sternal border and radiates to the carotids, which differs from the likely finding in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for acute mitral regurgitation (MR) secondary to papillary muscle dysfunction or rupture, a mechanical complication of an MI. The soft, decrescendo murmur is best heard at the cardiac apex on auscultation. In acute severe MR, this finding may be absent or difficult to detect due to rapid equalization of left atrial and ventricular pressures. The regurgitant blood flow from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole causes volume overload, leading to left ventricular dilation (laterally displaced point of maximal impulse) and pulmonary edema (bibasilar crackles), which explains this patient's heart failure symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue.

D) INCORRECT:

This describes the murmur of a ventricular septal defect. While interventricular septal rupture is a possible mechanical complication of an MI that can cause a new holosystolic murmur and heart failure, its murmur is characteristically heard at the left lower sternal border, not the apex. Ischemic mitral regurgitation is a more common complication.

E) INCORRECT:

This describes the murmur of aortic regurgitation. Acute aortic regurgitation can cause heart failure, but it is not a typical complication of an MI. It is more commonly associated with aortic dissection or infective endocarditis. Furthermore, the murmur is diastolic, whereas the most common valvular complication of an MI causes a systolic murmur.
questions.hint: A common mechanical complication following an MI is papillary muscle dysfunction, which leads to acute valvular insufficiency and heart failure.
